EGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

The Hydrogen Facility is located at 1310 East El Segundo Blvd, El Segundo, California, 90245 on the Chevron El Segundo Refinery property.  The facility's mailing address is 214 Main St., El Segundo, California, 90245.  The Hydrogen Facility's  is approximately 3.5 acres, and it is located in the south east corner of the refinery.  The area directly east of the facility is predominately zoned for heavy industrial activities.  However, to the South, residential property is located within approximately 0.4 miles.  Also, no environmental receptors have been identified within this area. 

The products from the Hydrogen Facility are hydrogen and steam.  The unit produces raw hydrogen, which is then purified. There are three types of feed stock for the unit: pentane, natural gas, and refinery fuel gas.  The Hydrogen Facility is designed to operate for nine months with pentane feed and refinery fuel gas. During the remaining three months of the year, the Hydrogen Facility operates with natural gas and refinery fuel gas.  Continuous operation with a mixture of all three types of feedstock is not foreseen.  The fuel for the reformer furnace is off-gas from the pressure swing adsorption unit, supplemented with refinery fuel gas or natural gas.

The pentane reformer feedstock meets the criteria for classification as a flammable mixture pursuant to the regulations at Title 19 of the California Code of Regulations (19 CCR), Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Section 2770.2 (b)(2).  The total quantity of pentane flammable mixture present at the facility is 33,264 pounds.  The pentane flammable mixture consists of butane (CAS# 106-97-8), isopentane (CAS# 78-78-4), and pentane (CAS# 109-66-0). The predominant component in this mixture is isopentane.  The quantity of pentane, as a flammable mixture, exceeds the 10,000 pound threshold for both the EPA RMP and CalARP regulations.
The facility also contains methane and hydrogen, which are regulated flammable substance

s pursuant to both the EPA RMP and CalARP requirements.  However, the quantities of these chemicals held on site at any time are below the 10,000-pound threshold for inclusion in either program.  Facility personnel have completed a determination for the quantities of all potentially regulated substances at the facility.  Refer to Appendix A2 for the calculations regarding both hydrogen and methane.

1.3    HAZARD ASSESSMENT RESULTS

To meet the EPA RMP and the CalARP regulations, the Hydrogen facility must analyze one worst-case release scenario that is estimated to create the greatest distance in any direction to the end point resulting from an accidental release of regulated flammable and toxic substances from covered processes under worst-case conditions.  Administrative controls and passive mitigation devices are present to mitigate off-site consequences, however none of these devices were considered in the Worst Case Scenario (WCS).  Historical data from industry reportable chemical accidents were reviewed to ensure a credible event was chosen.  All modeling was done with EPA RMP*Comp version 1.07.

1.3.1    WCS Flammable

The pentane feedstock meets the criteria for classification as a flammable mixture, which consists of butane, isopentane, and pentane.  The predominant component in this mixture is isopentane.  The largest quantity of this flammable mixture contained in a single location within the facility is at the pentane feed surge drum, V-100.  The maximum quantity of flammable mixture that could be contained in this vessel has been estimated at 30,754 pounds.  The worst-case scenario (WCS) associated with a flammable material at the Hydrogen Facility is a catastrophic failure of the feed surge drum due to over-pressurization from a fire near the tank.  The WCS has been modeled such that the entire contents of this vessel are released as a vapor within 10 minutes.  

EPA's RMP*Comp software was used to model this WCS.  The estimated impacts (distance to endpoi

In addition to the accidental release prevention program, the Hydrogen Facility has safety features designed to (1) quickly detect the release, (2) contain/control the release; (3) reduce the consequence of (mitigate) a release.  

The following types of safety features are used in various processes:
A?    Detection of Release: Several cameras have been installed in order to monitor releases/spills/fires in the process area remotely from the control room;    
A?    Release Containment/Control: A containment dike has been installed to mitigate the release of pentane from the feed surge vessel, V-100; and.    
A?    Release Mitigation: Twelve firewater monitors have been installed on the perimeter of the facility and are capable of cooling the process equipment.  Fire extinguishers are also installed throughout the facility. There are three combination safety shower/eye wash stations in the facility as well. 
Personal protective equipment is located at the facility. Employees in the operating area wear personal carbon monoxide monitors.  In addition, the City of El Segundo recently implemented a Mass Notification System that can alert citizens of emergencies via cell phone, text message, e-mail, or home phone.  Persons who are registered for notification s via the City's website (http://www.elsegundo.org/) will receive notifications for emergencies, including significant events at the refinery or Air Liquide that would affect surrounding residents. 
  
1.6    FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

CalARP regulations require facilities to compile a five-year accident history. This is defined as "all accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in death, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage" (19 CCR, Chapter 4.5, Section 2750.9). According to information provided by Air Liquide personnel,

there have been no accidental releases from the pentane tank that meet the above definition since the Hydrogen Facility was constructed in 2004.  
   
1.7    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION 

The Hydrogen Facility is designated as a non-responding plant, falling under Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations (40 CFR) CFR Section 68.90(b) with respect to the EPA RMP and under 19 CCR Division 2 Chapter 4.5 section 2765.2 with respect to CalARP. The El Segundo Hydrogen Facility employees are trained only to the First Responder Awareness Level, First Aid Fire Responder, and for First Aid and CPR.  The El Segundo Hydrogen Facility is located within the Chevron El Segundo refinery, and the facility, in cooperation with the refinery, has jointly reviewed the Air Liquide Emergency Action Plan to insure appropriate action can be taken in the event of an accidental release.  The Refinery Emergency Responders will perform emergency response for Air Liquide in the event of an accidental release.  The procedure for activating the Refinery's Emergency Notification System is found in the El Segundo SMR Emergency Action Plan, ELS-SMR-HS-0001K that was last reviewed on February 3, 2009.  This document describes the coordination of response activities with local response agencies, outside agency notification procedures, and provides detailed evacuation procedures in the event of an ammonia release and/or fire.  

If an emergency occurs that will have off-site consequences, a Unified Command structure will be established based on the Chevron El Segundo Refinery Emergency Response Plan.  The El Segundo Hydrogen Facility Emergency Response Coordinator will work with the Unified Command to ensure they are aware of the on-site hazardous materials and familiar with the El Segundo Hydrogen Facility Emergency Action Plan.
